docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. MARTIN LIZZUL An Easygoing Best Friend Martin Lizzul wanted to be everyone's best friend. You could not force a nasty word out of him. ''He was so easygoing,'' said his sister, Susan Lauria. ''He never said a bad word about anyone. Even if he didn't like someone, he wouldn't say a bad word.'' Mr. Lizzul, 31, was an account executive for Kestrel Technology, a software company, and for months he had been spending the mornings -- usually from 7:30 to 11 -- at Cantor Fitzgerald, a client that was using Kestrel products.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Israeli Politician's Slaying Leads to Talk of War The Israeli government cut off all contact with the Palestinian governing authority, as forces clashed in two West Bank cities and Israelis and Palestinians talked about assassination and war rather than any peace process a day after the killing of the Israeli tourism minister, Rehavam Zeevi. Diplomats who talked with Yasir Arafat described him as furious over Mr. Zeevi's killing, and said he believed that it had jeopardized all progress made toward peace in the last month. A1 Protestants Quit in Belfast Protestant leaders pulled out of the power-sharing government in Northern Ireland, but the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, said they would return if the I.R.A. began to disarm. A12

docs.lead_paragraph: During the 18 years of his fragile life, Nicolas Perruche has had little contact with the world around him. He cannot hear or speak and is largely blind. His heart is weak, and he moves only when carried or put into a wheelchair. Nicolas was born this way because his mother contracted German measles, an illness often harmful to the fetus. Four weeks into her pregnancy, Nicolas's mother told her doctor that she wanted an abortion if she had the disease, but a laboratory and the doctor failed to diagnose it.

headline.main: French Uproar Over Right to Death for Unborn

docs.abstract: French high court causes uproar with landmark ruling that damages must be paid to Nicolas Peruche and his family because his birth 18 years ago was result of medical error; decision is seen as signal that unborn child has right to be aborted, or at least that handicapped child has right to recognition that his or her birth was mistake; Peruche cannot hear or speak, is largely blind, has weak heart and must use wheelchair; advocacy group for the handicapped sues court over decision; photo; ethical issues discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In ''Riding in Cars With Boys,'' Drew Barrymore is required to age two decades, from a dizzy 15-year-old high school student in Wallingford, Conn., into a hardened New York journalist and author who is the bossy mother of a college-age son. The role of Beverly Donofrio in the film, adapted from Ms. Donofrio's memoir, is easily the most challenging of Ms. Barrymore's career, and in carrying it off she masters a tricky emotional balancing act. Snared by a teenage pregnancy into a marriage that eventually falls apart, Beverly reluctantly postpones her dream of a college education to bring up a resentful, if loving, son, Jason (Adam Garcia). Ms. Barrymore's tough-but-tender performance is the clearest proof yet that this 26-year-old actress, who shares the unofficial title of America's Sweetheart with Julia Roberts, has what it takes to stretch her talents into large, complex portrayals.

headline.main: A Girl's Charmed Life Detours Down a Bumpy Road

docs.lead_paragraph: A Manhattan obstetrician was sentenced yesterday to seven years and three months in prison and was ordered to pay $3.2 million in restitution for defrauding insurance companies to have them pay for expensive fertility procedures. The doctor, Niels H. Lauersen, had billed the companies for gynecological procedures that were covered by his patients' policies to mask the uncovered fertility procedures he was performing. In New York, insurance companies are required to pay for all gynecological problems deemed medically correctable, but not for procedures like in-vitro fertilization that are intended strictly to induce pregnancy.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a last-minute flurry over the weekend, Gov. Gray Davis signed into law sweeping new rights for domestic partners, stronger protections against harassment for those entering abortion clinics and some of the strictest requirements in the nation for prospective handgun buyers. The bills were among 120 that Governor Gray, a Democrat, signed on Sunday to meet a midnight deadline for approving bills passed in the final weeks of the legislative session. He also vetoed dozens of bills, including legislation that would increase workers' compensation benefits.

headline.main: California Strengthens Handgun Laws and Partners' Rights
